draw.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to produce a picture of something using a pencil, pen etc
draw.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Katie had drawn a cottage with a little stream running next to it.
She asked the little girl to draw a picture of the man she’d spoken to.
Keith was drawing a complicated-looking graph.
I’ve never been able to draw very well.
Can you draw me a map of how to get there?
draw.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to get a particular kind of reaction from someone
draw.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The movie drew praise from critics.
His remarks drew an angry response from Democrats.
draw.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to attract someone or make them want to do something
draw.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Beth felt strangely drawn to this gentle stranger.
The festival is likely to draw huge crowds.
What first drew you to teaching?
draw.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to get something that you need or want from someone or something
draw.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I drew a lot of comfort from her kind words.
Plants draw nourishment from the soil.
draw.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to move in a particular direction
draw.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: She drew away, but he pulled her close again.
The boat drew alongside us and a man appeared on the deck.
I arrived just as the train was drawing into the station.
draw.translation[0].definitions[4].note_: In everyday English, people usually use pull rather than draw:
The train was pulling into the station.
draw.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to move someone or something in a particular direction by pulling them gently
draw the curtains/a blind etc (=close them by pulling them gently)
draw.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Bobby drew a chair up to the table.
Hussain drew me aside to whisper in my ear.
draw.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: if an animal draws a vehicle, it pulls it along
draw.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: a carriage drawn by six horses
draw.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to take something out of a container, pocket etc
draw.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Maria drew her gun nervously and peered out into the gloom.
Ali reached into his pocket and drew out a piece of paper.
draw.translation[0].definitions[7].note_: In everyday English, people usually use pull something out or take something out rather than draw something out:
Ali reached into his pocket and pulled out a piece of paper.
draw.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to take money from your bank account
draw.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Hughes had drawn $8,000 in cash from a bank in Toronto.
draw.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to receive an amount of money regularly from a government or financial institution
draw.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: How long have you been drawing unemployment benefit?
I’ll be drawing my pension before he’ll ever get around to asking me to marry him!
draw.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to take air or smoke into your lungs
draw.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Ruth paused to draw breath, her voice barely hiding her excitement.
He lit his pipe and drew deeply.
draw.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to take a liquid from something such as a barrel or tap
draw.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to take water from a well
draw.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: if a fire or chimney draws, it lets the air flow through to make the fire burn well
draw.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: to choose by chance a ticket etc that will win a prize
draw.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: The winning ticket will be drawn at the Christmas Party.
draw.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: to finish without either side winning in a game such as football
draw.translation[0].definitions[16].defi: if a ship draws a particular depth, it needs that depth of water to float in
draw.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to make a picture, pattern etc using a pen or pencil
The children were asked to draw a picture of their families.
I’m going to art classes to learn how to draw.
to draw a picture of something or someone quickly and without a lot of detail
Roy took a pencil and sketched the bird quickly, before it moved.
to draw the pictures in a book
It’s a beautiful book, illustrated by Arthur Rackham.
to draw shapes or patterns without really thinking about what you are doing
He was on the phone, doodling on his notepad as he spoke.
to draw shapes or lines without making a definite picture or pattern. Small children do this before they have learned to draw or write
At the age of two, she loved scribbling with crayons and coloured pencils.
to copy a picture by putting a piece of thin paper over it and drawing the lines that you can see through the paper
First trace the map, and then copy it into your workbooks.
draw.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: the final result of a game or competition in which both teams or players have the same number of points
draw.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The match ended in a draw.
draw.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: an occasion when someone or something is chosen by chance, especially the winning ticket in a lottery, or the teams who will play against each other in a competition
draw.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: England has been selected to play Germany in the draw for the first round of the World Cup.
draw.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a competition in which people whose names or tickets are chosen by chance win money or prizes
draw.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: Congratulations! You have been entered into our £100,000 prize draw!
draw.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a performer, place, event etc that a lot of people come to see
draw.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: It is hoped that the new art gallery will be a big draw for visitors.
draw.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: when you breathe in smoke from a cigarette
draw.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: Maltravers took a long draw on his cigarette.
draw.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to take money from your bank account
draw.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Many credit cards can now be used to draw cash from ATMs around the world.
All the money in his account has been drawn out.
draw.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to receive an amount of money regularly from your employer or from the government
draw.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: In the first year of the partnership, Jenny drew a salary of £30,000.
You are entitled to draw unemployment benefit.
draw.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to write out and sign a cheque or BANK ORDER
draw.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: I’ll draw a cheque on the company account.
draw.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to write a BILL OF EXCHANGE
draw.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: Bills are drawn by the exporter on the issuing or confirming bank.
